_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: STORAGE TANKS, VALVES, PIPING, NURSE TANKS AND HOSES

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
THE OTTAWA COOPERATIVE ASSOCIATION IS AN AGRICULTURAL RETAILER THAT SPECIALIZES IN GRAIN STORAGE AND THE SALE OF AGRICULTURAL INPUTS FOR PRODUCTION.  THE TOTAL CAPACITY OF OUR NH3 PLANT IS 218,000 TOTAL POUNDS.  THE PLANT CONSISTS OF 1-18,000 AND 1-12,000 GALLON TANKS 20-1000 GALLON NURSE TANKS.

THE WORST CASE SCENARIO WOULD BE THE RELEASE OF THE  TOTAL CONTENTS OF THE LARGEST STORAGE TANK WHICH INCLUDES 79,000 POUNDS.  THE DISTANCE TO ENDPOINT WOULD BE 1.89 MILES AND HAS THE POTENTIAL TO AFFECT 2500 AREA RESIDENTS.  THE ALTERNATIVE RELEASE WOULD HAVE A RUPTURE OF A TRANSFER HOSE, RELEASING 11,908 POUNDS AND HAVE A DISTANCE TO ENDPOINT OF .83 MILES AFFECTING NEARLY 1200 CITIZENS.

THE FACILITY HAS IMPLEMENTED THE PROVISIONS OF ANSI K-61, OSHA 29 CFR 1910.111 AS WELL AS THE KANSAS DEPT OF AGRICULTURE.  THE STATE INSPECTS OUR PLANT ON A ANNUAL BASIS AND WE COMPLY WITH ALL THEIR REQUEST FOR IMPROVEMENT.  OUR EMPLOYEES ARE TRAINED ON A REGULAR BASIS IN GENERAL SAFETY, THE HAZARDS OF AMMONIA, OPERATING PROCEDURES AND MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES OF A TYPICAL FACILITY.  THE EMPLOYEES ALWAYS WEAR THE APPROPRIATE GLOVES AND GOGGLES DURING LOADING OPERATIONS.  ADDITIONALLY, CLEAN SAFETY WATER IS ON HAND DURING NURSE TANK FILLING OPERATIONS.  WITH THIS IN MIND, IT'S ESPECIALLY EASY TO REPORT THAT NO ACCIDENTAL RELEASES HAVE OCCURED AT THIS LOCATION WITHIN THE LAST FIVE YEARS.

THIS FACILITY HAS A WRITTEN EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN AND HAS BEEN SHARED WITH THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT.  THE FIRE DEPT IS AWARE OF THE DANGERS OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA AND THEY'VE AGREED TO ASSIST IN THE EVENT OF AN EMERGENCY INCIDENT.   

THE OTTAWA COOP IS COMMITTED TO SAFETY. THERE ARE MANY HAZARDS ASSOCIATED WITH AMMONIA. ALTHOUGH THERE IS A PROPANE STORAGE TANK IN THE AREA OF THE AMMONIA PLANT, WE AT THIS TIME FEEL THAT IS POSES NO THREAT TO THE AMMONIA PLANT OR THE AMMONIA PLANT TO THE PROPANE STORAGE. WE REQUIRE THAT EACH EMPLOYEE THAT LOADS AMMONIA BE TRAINED EVERY THREE YEARS AT A STATE SPONSERED TRAINI

NG SCHOOL AND YEARLY TRAINED IN OPERATING AND SAFETY PROCEEDURES AT A GIVEN AMMONIA PLANT. ALL EMPLOYEES ARE TRAINED TO INSPECT THE AMMONIA PLANT BEFORE FILLING PROCEEDURES AND BEFORE USE DO A VISUAL INSPECTON OF ALL HOSES AND VALVES TO MAKE SURE THERE HAS NOT BEEN A FAILURE OF EQUIPMENT SINCE THE LAST TIME IT WAS USED. ALL RUST SPOTS ON STORAGE AND NURSE TANKS WILL BE CLEANED AND PAINTED TO KEEP RUST TO A MINIMUM. EMPLOYEES ARE REMINDED TO FOLLOW START UP PROCEEDURES BEFORE FILLING AND DURING FILLING NURSE TANKS. ALL ACCIDENTAL RELEASES OF AMMONIA WILL BE REPORTED TO LOCAL AUTHORITIES AND TO THE KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE. IF AFTER ANALIZING RELEASE IT IS FOUND THAT 100 POUNDS OF AMMONIA WAS RELEASED THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER WILL BE NOTIFIED.

WE HAVE IDENTIFIED THE FOLLOWING AS POTENTIAL HAZARDS TO OUR EMPLOYEES AND COMMUNITY.
1. THEFT OF AMMONIA AND POSSIBLE UNCLOSED VALVES TO COMMUNITY AND EMPLOYEES                 
2. RUPTURE OF HOSES IN LOADING OF NURSE TANKS AND UNLOADING OF SEMI-TRAILERS
3. DRIVING OFF OF CUSTOMER'S WHILE HOSE IS STILL HOOKED TO NURSE TANKS
4. FAILURE IN HYDROSTATIC OR PRESSURE RELIEF VALVE
5. VEHICLE DRIVING INTO FILL STAND OR PIPING
6. OVERFILLING OF NURSE TANK AND LIQUID AMMONIA GOING INTO VAPOR LINE
7. HEATING OF THE DAY CAUSING RISE IN PRESSURE IN STORAGE TANK OR NURSE TANK CAUSING IT TO RELIEVE PRESSURE
ALL EMPLOYEES ARE AWARE OF THESE HAZARDS AND ARE INSTRUCTED TO LOOK FOR THESE HAZARDS IN THEIR EVERYDAY WORKPLACE AND TAKE NECESSARY PRECAUTIONS.
